The employees are instructed to make emergency phone calls in this order:  911, the facility Manager, the site and business EHS support, the state emergency hotline and the National Spill Response Center phone number.  All applicable contact names and numbers are found in the facility spill and emergency action plan. 

Communication procedures with responders

The local fire department is invited to tour the facility on an annual basis.  Facility management, employees and fire department personnel have jointly discussed the location of the flammable liquid process and storage areas and response procedures on a regular basis.  They know the location of all emergency shutoff valves and on-site response equipment.  We believe that a strong relationship with first responders is our best defense.

The LEPC and state regulatory agencies receive a copy of our hazardous materials storage information annually, in accordance with our community right to know obligations, to help facilitate coordinating emergency response planning involving materials at our facility.

Security Plans

The Department of Transportation (DOT), Research and Special Programs Administration (RSPA) 49 CFR Part 172, requires all facilities that offer or transport hazardous materials to document a security plan and perform employee awareness training.  

A security assessment plan has been created to describe all security measures at this facility, identify any vulnerable areas and then document the measures taken to address those risks.  The plan is intended to work in conjunction with the Emergency Action and Spill Prevention, Control and Countermeasures Plan to meet all required criteria.

Training is performed with all employees annually and within 90 days of employment.

on file at the facility and in the electronic incident management system.

A formal Management of Change (MOC) system is in place at this facility.  An electronic form is submitted whenever a change is made to any of the processes within the scope of the PSM program. This ensures that appropriate documentation such as P&IDs, operating procedures, maintenance items, etc. are reviewed and updated as needed where affected by the change.  Forms are routed from the facility operator to the Engineering and business EHS support for review and remarks.  Where changes affect operating procedures, revisions are made and employee training is completed prior to start-up of the changed process.  A copy of the completed is form kept on file at the facility.

The facility maintains compliance with environmental permits applicable to the operations.  These permits include various requirements for weekly, monthly, and quarterly activities to prevent leaks or uncontrolled emissions of flammable materials.

Monthly Safety Committee meetings allow employees to discuss any concerns they may have with the operation of the facility.  Issues are documented and assigned to employees for follow-up. Records of all meetings are kept at the facility.

Response Action in the Event of a Release

The site has not had a significant accident within the last five years for one or more of the regulated substances from a covered process.

In the event of a small, controlled leak or defective valve, employees are instructed to shut down the transfer process and, if possible, don the appropriate PPE, approach the shutoff valve from upwind and attempt to turn it off.  Notification of site personnel would be made as soon as possible when the leak has been detected. 

For an uncontainable release, employees will immediately call the police and fire department or other first responders, as appropriate.  All employees, customers and contractors are to be evacuated to an upwind location. Once the response tea

xplanation.

Training

All employees receive annual training on flammable liquids, emergency action plan, spill procedures, and hazard communication.  Documentation and attendance rosters are on file at the facility.  

Contractors

Contractors that are hired by THE ANDERSONS MARATHON HOLDINGS LLC will go through a documented Prequalification process.  Records of this evaluation are kept on file.

All contractors also receive a contractor safety review prior to performing work at the facility.  During this review, they are informed of any potential hazards at the facility, emergency procedures, site-specific safety rules and the ability to request a SDS for any product at any time.

Steps Taken to Address Hazards

The Andersons has many systems in place for hazard assessment and mitigation.  

A Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) has been performed at this facility, as part of the Process Safety Management Program.  The analysis will be updated every five years, or as changes in the processes are made.  PHA's are performed using the What-If/Checklist protocol and analyze all aspects involved in the production of ethanol.  The evaluation team includes representatives from the business EHS support, facility Management and Operations employees.

Standard operating procedures have been established for all activities related to the natural gasoline storage and handling.  These procedures are reviewed annually by employees and management to ensure they are current.  The procedures are available to the employees at the facility in hard copy and in an electronic database. 

Pre-startup safety reviews are conducted prior to start-up after major shutdowns and/or changes to the process.  These reviews ensure that the process has been restored to a safe operating condition prior to beginning operations.  The reviews are documented and those forms are kept on file at the facility.

Formal investigations are performed for all environmental or safety incidents.  Documentation is kept

bserved by facility personnel.  If a release were to occur the attendants could stop the flow within minutes.  The loadout area where deliveries occur has a catchment basin with underground piping to secondary containment.

Explanation on prevention of Natural Gasoline releases:

Passive Mitigation
The natural gasoline storage and unloading areas are equipped with secondary containment.  Material released from unloading will stay in the concrete secondary containment pad.  Electrical equipment in the tank farm area is rated for Class 1 Division 1 to prevent any leakage from being ignited by electrical equipment. 

Active Mitigation
Hot work in the unloading area and tank farm is strictly controlled by hot work permits.  Unloading operations are attended at all times.  All of the fire hydrant(s) around the tank farm are equipped with water cannons to allow for fire suppression/control from a safe distance.  

Accident History
The site has not had a release accident involving natural gasoline in the last five years.

Prevention Program

Preventive maintenance is an integral piece of this facility's hazard management program.  All hoses, tanks, valves and storage units are inspected at least monthly.  A good PM program is our strongest defense against a release of natural gasoline.  All hose replacements are documented.  Records of all maintenance tasks performed on the tank or appendages are also on file.

This facility uses a certified third party contractor for all welding and construction performed on the natural gasoline tank and transfer pipes.  Copies of all reports are on file. The natural gasoline system undergoes a thorough inspection by a third party at least every five years.

See Steps Taken to Address Hazards for more information on prevention measures and identification.


Management System

(see Steps Taken to Address Hazards)

Equipment maintenance

All equipment maintenance is formally documented. See the Prevention Program section for further e

vents.  The thermal oxidizers are very efficient at controlling particulates, carbon monoxide, VOC's, HAP's and nuisance odors.

The facility also has a water cooling tower for non-contact cooling water. Cooling is needed in distillation and fermentation. 

The facility is protected from fire with a high pressure fire water loop and sprinklers in high risk areas.   Also there is a central fire detection and alarm system. 


RMP Applicability & Chemical Description

The chemical that requires participation in the Risk Management Plan is natural gasoline. Natural gasoline is used to denature the ethanol.  Natural gasoline is a flammable mixture.  There are multiple constituents of natural gasoline however, based on analysis, four of those constituents, butane, pentane, isobutane, and iso-pentane or 2-methylbutane are subject to the Risk Management Plan.  Butane makes up 15% of the natural gasoline, pentane makes up 20%, isobutane makes up 9.5%, and iso-pentane or 2-methylbutane makes up 23%.

Natural gasoline is stored in a 235,000 gallon steel tank in the facility's tank farm.  Secondary containment consisting of compacted clay surrounds the tank farm.

Summary of Release Scenarios

Worst Case Release

Natural Gasoline:
The worst case release scenario would be a total loss of a full tank of natural gasoline resulting in a vapor cloud explosion.  The storage tank capacity is 235,000 gallons or just under 1.3 million pounds.  Of the 1.3 million pounds, about 880,000 pounds are made up of the materials subject to the Risk Management Plan.

Alternative Release

Natural Gasoline:
The most likely cause of a natural gasoline emergency is a release during a delivery due to a faulty hose or valve resulting in a vapor cloud explosion.  Deliveries are made by railcar and pumped into the storage tank.  Deliveries are typically 30,000 gallons or 166,000 pounds of which about 110,000 pounds are RMP materials.

ANDERSONS MARATHON HOLDINGS LLC
Executive Summary
Site and Process Description

THE ANDERSONS MARATHON HOLDINGS LLC is located at 3389 West County Road 300 South.  The facility is located in Cass County, Clinton Township. The site is north of State road 25 and west of County Road 325 west. 

The Clymers facility operates 24 hours a day, 7 days a week with a staff of approximately 60 people.  The following operations are performed at this facility:  grain receiving and storage; hammer milling; fermentation; distillation, dehydration and evaporation (DDE); Corn oil extraction. Stillage and syrup is dried to produce DDGs (Dried Distillers Grain with soluble). The finished products are wet and dry distillers grain (WDGS / DDGS), corn oil, denatured ethanol, and E85 ethanol.  These products are shipped out via trucks and rail.

The plant receives corn by way of the pre-existing grain elevator or the new secondary truck dump at the ethanol plant.  Grain is stored temporarily in the concrete silos or steel grain bins, prior to being fed to hammer mills where the corn is dry-milled into a powder and then conveyed to the production area.

The corn flour is mixed with water, enzymes, and yeast; then is fermented to produce ethanol beer.  The gases produced in fermentation are scrubbed with water to remove VOCs and then discharged to atmosphere. The beer is distilled to produce 190 proof ethanol and whole stillage. The 190 proof ethanol is dried to 200 proof and is denatured with natural gasoline to produce denatured ethanol and E85 ethanol finished products.  These products are shipped via rail or trucks.

The whole stillage is dried using evaporators and dryers to produce DDGs at 12% moisture or WDGS at 50% moisture.  DDGs is shipped via truck and rail.  The WDGS is shipped truck only.

Corn oil is extracted from the thin stillage. It is shipped by truck and rail.

Thermal oxidizers serve as the primary emission control devices for the DDGS dryers as well as various process
